subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 778
msgSnippet: ... From: J. B. Rainsberger  ... What you describe was a management problem, not a problem with unit testing done by someone other
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>


>
> So said Lauren Bish on 2/21/2003 --------------------
>
> I agree with this 100% provided the word "unit" is removed. My fears:
>
> * The extra tests make refactoring more difficult, by testing the unit
> too deeply
> * I didn't write the extra tests, so I'm not sure I'll understand them
> -- although if we pair, have coding standards and collective code
> ownership, then this is less of an issue
>
> When I worked at IBM, I had people in QA write bug reports whenever the
> internal implementation of my component changed, even if it did not
> affect the outward-facing behavior of the component. This happened at
> least once per month and annoyed the hell out of me. Why is QA trying
> to do my unit testing? My standard question to them: "Does the system
> work?" When they replied "yes", my next question was, "Then what the
> hell are you worried about?"
>
> --"You moved such-and-such file..."
> --"This XML entry changed..."
>
> To me, that's not what they should worry about. That just wastes
> everyone's time: their time for worrying about it and my time for
> dealing with the non-issue.
>
> That's why I don't like the idea of someone else doing my unit testing.
> Any other kind of testing is cool, but not my unit testing. When it
> comes to Programmer Tests, only programmers need apply. The rest should
> test some other way.

What you describe was a management problem, not a problem with unit testing
done by someone other than the author of the code. I have seen such
overzealousness from time to time to - it is one of the reasons why we had a
triage team made up of representatives of different disciplines. Such bug
reports are the sign of an inexperienced tester and they need to be
educated. If they are testing too deeply then someone needs to make them
aware of that. I always had people test the API first, and treat the units
as black boxes, just at a unit level. Such an approach is a lot more
productive than trying to walk through the code and writing tests for the
implemenation - it is not the proper level of abstraction for the tests; the
implementation often changes, but the interface usually doesn't or shouldn't
(once it becomes halfway stable) - if the interface is changing then you
have a real problem.

Also, as I stated in my posts several times, the independent unit testers
were indeed programmers, not QA or testing people - or at least not solely
just testing people. They were trained and mentored by people like me who
have experience in both disciplines about how to test properly and how to
write code properly. Some worked out, some did not, but all learned from it,
including the people doing the training and mentoring.

Again, there were two factors involved that greatly improved unit testing;
independent eyes creating the tests, and a testing
mentality/aptitude/attitude. I do believe there is a lot of value in
independent unit testing.

FWIW,
Lauren
